G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: In accordance with G.L. c. 208, § 28, a custody or parenting time order may be modified if there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and if such modification is in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: This Honorable Court has subject matter jurisdiction over this action pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, and venue is appropriate in this Court under G.L. c. 223, § 1.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently emphasize that the paramount consideration in custody or parenting time matters is the best interests of the child. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal and custody determinations, the child’s best interests are the paramount concern and interprets the removal statute’s “cause shown” language to mean that removal must be in the child’s best interests. The court then applies that best-interests standard in analyzing both custody and removal, confirming that Massachusetts courts treat the child’s best interests as the controlling consideration in such matters.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts courts consistently emphasize that the paramount consideration in custody or parenting time matters is the best interests of the child. See Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704 (1985); Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981).
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in deciding custody issues, the court’s overriding concern must be the promotion of the children’s best interests and welfare, citing earlier Massachusetts precedent. It repeatedly applies a “best interests” analysis to custody and visitation determinations, thus directly affirming the principle that the paramount consideration in custody/parenting time matters is the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare. … The ‘best interests’ principle requires that the narrow focus be on the interests of the child. ‘[P]arents [too often] cannot be relied upon to assert the best interests of the children] adequately because of their conflicting economic and psychological stakes in the outcome’ (footnotes omitted).”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: A material change warranting modification has occurred here, as the Defendant’s move to Cape Cod and the long commute Sophie endures on school nights have impaired her well-being and educational performance. See Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012) (material changes in physical or educational circumstances as grounds for modification).
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion in Hunter v. Rose does not address modification of an existing custody or support order based on later-arising material changes in a child’s physical or educational circumstances. Its custody analysis is a first-instance, best-interests determination focusing on parental alienation, stability, and relocation choices at the time of the initial judgment, not on a post‑judgment change warranting modification. The proposition that material changes in physical or educational circumstances constitute grounds for modification is therefore not supported by this case.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’…. The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent.”

Ducey v. Ducey, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 673 (1.raw_text: Ducey v. Ducey, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 673 (1988)
Ducey v. Ducey, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 673 (1.proposition: Courts have determined that minimizing disruptions to a child’s education and routine is critical to a child’s best interests. See Ducey v. Ducey, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 673 (1988); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Ducey v. Ducey, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 673 (1.support_reasoning: The case excerpt provided is a criminal appeal about evidentiary issues (cross‑examination of a defense witness regarding pending charges and exclusion of a prior inconsistent statement). It does not discuss child custody, relocation, or any best-interests-of-the-child analysis, nor does it mention a child’s education or routine. Therefore, Ducey v. Ducey, as presented here, does not support the proposition about minimizing disruptions to a child’s education and routine being critical to the child’s best interests.
Ducey v. Ducey, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 673 (1.relevant_excerpt: [No relevant excerpt. The opinion concerns evidentiary rulings in a criminal armed robbery case and does not address child custody, best-interests standards, or educational/routine stability for children.]

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: Courts have determined that minimizing disruptions to a child’s education and routine is critical to a child’s best interests. See Ducey v. Ducey, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 673 (1988); Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The concurrence in Smith v. McDonald does not focus on school continuity or daily routine in the traditional removal/relocation sense, but it explicitly stresses that maintaining an existing parenting arrangement and avoiding disruption of a child’s stability is central to the child’s best interests. By quoting and endorsing Custody of Kali’s statement that unnecessary disruption of an established arrangement is contrary to a child’s best interests and that stability is of "enormous benefit," the opinion provides authority for the more general principle that minimizing disruptions to a child’s established situation is critical to the child’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not *558disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ("If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement, and contrary to the child’s best interest to disrupt it. Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child, and any unnecessary tampering with the status quo simply increases the risk of harm to the child").

Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.raw_text: Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: The requested modification is narrowly tailored to meet Sophie’s needs while ensuring that meaningful parenting time continues between the Defendant and Sophie. See Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015).
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns whether a requested modification is narrowly tailored to meet a child’s needs while preserving meaningful parenting time. Schechter addresses custody, a one‑year suspension of visitation, and removal standards, but it does not articulate or apply any ‘narrow tailoring’ requirement, nor does it emphasize preserving meaningful parenting time in the face of abuse; instead, it upholds a complete one‑year moratorium on contact. Therefore, the case does not provide authority for the specific proposition cited.
Schechter v. Schechter, 88 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: “The judge added that… ‘Continuing to allow supervised contact between [the father] and [the child] is a recipe for continued misery. No list of rules prohibiting certain behaviors could ever encompass all the ways [the father] will find to harass, intimidate, berate, and manipulate all those involved. The hard reality is that it is in [the child’s] best interest to place a moratorium on any communication or contact between him and his father.’”

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.proposition: Where the childcare arrangement causes exhaustion and disrupts a child’s education, Massachusetts courts have recognized that modification is appropriate to protect the child’s welfare. See Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998); Gupta v. Naik, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 120 (2021).
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: Rosenberg v. Merida concerns child support calculation (including credits for SSDI dependency benefits), attachment of assets, and the standard for modifying legal custody. It does not address childcare arrangements, exhaustion, disruption of a child’s education, or modification of parenting time/physical custody based on such factors. The portion on custody only discusses lack of communication between parents and the need for best-interests findings, not education-disrupting childcare schedules, so the case does not support the cited proposition.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’ … However, the judge ‘failed to make specific or detailed findings … that awarding sole legal custody of the minor child to the defendant was in the best interests of the child.’ We thus cannot sustain the award.”

Gupta v. Naik, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 120 (20.raw_text: Gupta v. Naik, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 120 (2021)
Gupta v. Naik, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 120 (20.proposition: Where the childcare arrangement causes exhaustion and disrupts a child’s education, Massachusetts courts have recognized that modification is appropriate to protect the child’s welfare. See Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998); Gupta v. Naik, 99 Mass. App. Ct. 120 (2021).
